Let's talk about #pacing. When I got sick with #longCOVID I spoke to a rehab physio who told me I had to pace. I thought this meant "slow down" but I was so very wrong.

Why are we not talking about these things in the context HigherEd and academia? This is not only about the ever growing cohort of people dealing with #longcovid, it's an opportunity to create better work conditions for students & professionals with disabilities in general.

Excellent look at #LongCovid on BBC Wales radio.
(I'm one of the patients interviewed.)
https://t.co/IJ5UTqxhMn
I worry about students that suddenly have found themselves in the position of caretakers of someone with #longcovid. Who is accommodating them, where are the policies protecting these people?

I worry about how search committees will accommodate folks like me, applying for jobs while dealing with #longcovid. I cannot physically handle the fast pace of academic interviews without it leaving me bed bound from post-exertional malaise #PEM #MECFS

I worry about students who are ill are being left out of activities/opportunities based on assumptions and inability of faculty and admin in being understanding, having empathy & properly accommodating folks with disability & chronic illness.  #LongCovid.

I worry about the students who don't have access to health care & won't be able to provide medical documentation in order to get approved for academic accommodations. I worry about those who do have access to health care, but are being gaslit as nearly everyone with #LongCovid.

I worry about the lack of understanding of what covid19 recovery actually looks like & what #LongCovid entails. For most, symptoms wax and wane in an unpredictable way. People need to educate themselves on what this looks like for folks living it. https://t.co/YVMVeBqjT8

As I hit the 7th month mark dealing with #LongCovid, I grow concerned about how Higher Ed and academia are failing to support and accommodate undergrads, grad students & early career folks trying to deal with a novel disease that may cause chronic illness and disability.

Let's talk about #pacing. When I got sick with #longCOVID I spoke to a rehab physio who told me I had to pace. I thought this meant "slow down" but I was so very wrong. 
Pacing, true pacing, means breaking up your day into bit sized chunks and actively scheduling rest periods

Let's talk about #pacing. When I got sick with #longCOVID I spoke to a rehab physio who told me I had to pace. I thought this meant "slow down" but I was so very wrong. 
Pacing, true pacing, means breaking up your day into bit sized chunks and actively scheduling rest periods

I'm curious.

One in ten people who have overcome coronavirus continue to experience symptoms. 80% are women between 36 and 50 years old. They demand that #LongCovid  be declared an "occupational disease" - interpreted as granting eligibility for out of work benefits https://t.co/AbZw8QnXE7

It's so important that #longcovid is recognised as part of the wider problem of #postviralsyndrome #ME #CFS. PVS is a syndrome, not a disease, which means we don't understand the pathology or subgroups. #longcovid is one part of that puzzle, each deserves equal research and care
